abstract.para: To set up 2FA on &productname;, you need an available TOTP application of your choice. Then run a command to configure the authorization. The following sections provide details on how to proceed with the configuration of 2FA and also give instructions in situations when your 2FA fails.

section.title: Applications providing TOTP 2FA
section.para: The following applications providing 2FA are supported on &productname;.

listitem.para: PSONO - available for Firefox, Chrome, Docker, iOS, Android
Bitwarden - available as a Web browser extension, or as a desktop, mobile and Web application
Google Authenticator - available on Android, iOS and Wear OS
Okta Verify - available on Android, iOS, macOS and Windows
Yubico Authenticator - with a hardware key
KeePassXC - available on Linux desktops, Windows and macOS

section.title: Setting up 2FA
section.para: Each user can configure its 2FA or &rootuser; can configure it for any regular user of the system. To set up 2FA for a user from a running system, proceed as follows.

step.para: Scan the code to any TOTP application mentioned above.
Confirm the process by entering an OTP code.

section.title: Recovering access
section.para: Setting up 2FA is optional, however, once set the second factor is mandatory to login to &cockpit;. If the second factor becomes unvailable, you can change it or disable it. Even without the second factor, you can still login to the machine using SSH or directly from a console. After login, you can use the following two options:
